text:
I want to be your friend, too. I had a feeling last year that something was going to happen. It felt like you fell from heaven. I don’t think I’ll sleep tonight. Zosimov was worried he might go mad, so we shouldn’t upset him.

“What do you mean?” the mother cried.

“Did the doctor really say that?” Avdotya Romanovna asked, worried.

“Yes, but it’s not true at all. He gave him some medicine, a powder, I saw it. It would have been better if you had come tomorrow. It’s good that we left. In an hour, Zosimov will tell you everything. He’s not drunk! And I won’t be drunk either. Why did I drink so much? Because they got me into an argument! I’ve promised never to argue again! They talk such nonsense! I almost got into a fight! I left my uncle in charge. Can you believe they want everyone to be the same and not be themselves? They think that’s the best way to improve. If only their nonsense was their own, but it’s not…”

“Listen!” Pulcheria Alexandrovna said quietly, but it just made him more upset.

“What do you think?” Razumihin shouted, even louder. “Do you think I’m mad at them for talking nonsense? Not at all! I like when they talk nonsense. That’s what makes us human. You find the truth through mistakes!”

**PAGE SUMMARY:** Razumihin expresses his belief that making mistakes is essential to discovering truth and individuality.
